An image of a baby born with deformities claims that the baby was suffering from coronavirus. This image is of a stillborn baby suffering from anencephaly, which caused the baby to be born without parts of the brain/skull.

Two audio clips stating that the Mumbai police commissioner is going to enforce strict actions during the 21-day lockdown in India and that there will be a spike in cases after March 27, 2020. Mumbai Police officials denied that this audio was of the city police commissioner. The voices in both the videos were different.
Says certain states are banning the sale of alcohol. Claims that states are banning alcohol sales appear to have originated on a prank page.
“We inherited a broken test” for COVID-19. There was no inherited test because a test couldn’t be created until the new virus had emerged.

A satellite map by the Royal Dutch Meteorology Institute (KNMI) showed lowered nitrogen levels since the coronavirus crisis, which would supposedly indicate nitrogen levels in the Netherlands are unrelated to the Dutch agricultural sector. The satellite images only show nitrogen oxide levels (NOₓ) and leave out ammonia levels (NH₃), the compound which is responsible for the lion's share of nitrogen emission and is emitted predominantly by the agricultural sector.
Video shows re-opened wet market in China . The video dates back to 2017 and was recorded in Indonesia. Wet markets are currently closed down in Hubei.

Prof. Shenme Minzi from Zanjan University said lemon cure is helpful for COVID-19. There is no Zanjan University in China (it's in Iran), and no researcher named Shenme Minzi. Lemon contains Vitamin C which is helpful to empower the immune system but does not cure the disease.
A headline alleges that the first pregnant woman with coronavirus gave birth in Macedonia. The event did not happen in Macedonia, but in Serbia.

Iceland is testing its entire population. In Iceland, 3.5% of the population has been tested so far, according to the government. Iceland is doing a massive testing, with an average of 582 tests every day since mid-March. But even at this rate, it would take more than a year and a half to test all of the residents.

France needs tests for its population; however, Paris sent tests to Algeria. A thousand tests have been sent to Algeria to slow the spread of the coronavirus epidemic. But it was the Institut Pasteur which sent them to the other establishments in its international network, and not the French state.

A set of claims passed as instructions to be followed during the COVID-19 pandemic period. Some of the claims about COVID-19 are true. However, it contains factually incorrect claims such as drinking hot beverages can kill the novel coronavirus and coronavirus remains in throat and can be digested by the stomach if we intake enough fluids.

Restrictions to transit by your ID-number due to coronavirus. Even there are some restrictions and schedules to transit and buy, they are not by ID-numbers in Venezuela. Text in Whatsapp mixes measures from Colombia, Bolivia and Ecuador.

Sri Lanka’s KDU hospital will be dedicated to treat only VIP COVID-19 patients. Hospital director, chief epidemiologist and defense secretary all refuted the claim and said the hospital is ready to admit any patient.

Post claiming that Myanmar found COVID-19 treatment medicine called “chlorofos,” a medicine to treat malaria. The post also claims “chlorofos” is one of the WHO’s selected medicines to treat COVID-19. There is no evidence or recommendation from WHO for possible COVID-19 treatment using “chlorofos” but we found that “chloroquine” is used as a potential medicine in some countries. The WHO has reiterated that there is no single medicine effective for curing COVID-19 as yet.
Video shows that the Italian government/Brisbane police used zombie robots/drones to chase their citizen and make them stay home. The video was a prank scene filmed in 2016 in Brazil.

Video shows a supermarket in Louisiana had a breakdown: People were plundering goods with armed soldiers onsite. The video documented that Mexican people were robbing a supermarket to protest against the rising cost of gasoline in January 2017.

COVID-19 can be removed with a blow dryer on the nose or with a pot of boiling water. Home remedies to remove COVID-19 with a hair dryer or a pot with boiling water are false, dangerous and without any scientific basis.
According to the Mexican Health secretary, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador has COVID-19. The health secretary did not confirm that the president has COVID-19.

Ronaldo Caiado, governor of the Brazilian state Goiás, was beaten up due to his lockdown decrees. A gallery of photos proves it. Images that support the claim were taken in 2013, and the man being kicked is just a lookalike.

Video shows the suicide of an American man because he is infected with coronavirus. The video is from a 2015 suicide of a 37-year-old American man at Center City’s Embassy Suites Hotel in Philadelphia.

Myanmar president and state counselor are under 14 days quarantine after meeting with a COVID-19 patient from Switzerland. State counselor addressed COVID-19 updates a few hours after the post is published. Presidential office spokesperson U Zaw Htay has confirmed to media that both president and state counselor are not in quarantine.
UN is giving humanitarian aid in coronavirus emergency. UN is not delivering food aid. The message is a phishing scam.
Rubbing mustard oil on your nostrils can prevent coronavirus. Rubbing mustard oil cannot prevent coronavirus.
PM Modi announced internet suspension due to viral fake news related to COVID-19. The news bulletin image is digitally edited. No announcement of an internet ban was made by PM Modi.

Indian state of Madhya Pradesh’s government has issued an order to shoot at sight due to failure at lockdown implementation. No shoot at sight order was issued by Madhya Pradesh Govt., the State government have issued a clarification regarding this.

Home Ministry of India has issued an order that sharing of any news related to coronavirus is a punishable offense under the IT Act. The viral order is fake and was not issued by the Home Ministry of India.

Iranian child celebrity Anahita is suffering from COVID-19. The family of the girl denied the claim on the girl's Instagram account. The girl also appeared on a 3/30/20 video and is appearing healthy.

The government is not getting the test to detect COVID-19 from the company Genomica because it is run by the sister of a former opposition minister. The Ministry of Health has acquired the Genomica tests and those of Cestest, another Spanish company cited in the viral messages. None produces quick tests, but kits to do PCR tests.
Castilla La-Mancha prohibits the use of adapted diving masks in patients with COVID-19. The Castilla-La Mancha Health Service ensures that its use "is left to the professionals' discretion."

Costa Rica is at the peak stage of the virus. Health authorities and experts explain that it is impossible to determine exactly when the maximum point of infections of the novel coronavirus will appear.

Sneezing spreads droplets as far as 8 meters, and these droplets can stay suspended in the air for up to 24 hours. The velocity of sneezing is up to 35 meters per second. How long the coronavirus survives in the air depends on temperature, humidity, and the level of ventilation of the environment. Although droplets can travel and suspend in the air for a long time, the virus doesn't.

Chewing betel nuts can prevent COVID-19 infection. The WHO has iterated that while some traditional medicines, western medicines, and home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence of a single medicine to prevent COVID-19 currently. The WHO has confirmed that betel nut is carcinogenic.
French summer holidays have been rescheduled to the end of July. The original dates haven't been changed.

Says Nancy Pelosi’s “daughter is on the board of the Kennedy Center so that’s why it was so important to send them all that money.” None of House Speaker Nancy Pelosi’s children is on the Kennedy Center’s board. Pelosi is an ex-officio board member. So are several top Republican lawmakers.

People in italy are dropping their money on the streets because of COVID-19 crisis. The original photo belongs to an old non-valuable currency that has been replaced with a new one in Venezuela. The money on the street is from bank robbers after they realized they stole useless currency.

Azan (islamic prayer call) is said from an old mosque in Granada for the first time after 500 years because of COVID-19. The mosque in the video is in Balakan in Azerbaijan not Granada and the voice on the video belongs to the Iranian Mahdy Yarahi.
Video of the funeral of coronavirus patients in Italy who died. The video is an excerpt from a scene in the television series titled "Pandemic," which aired in 2007.
Inhaling hot steam can kill the coronavirus. This virus is in the body cells even though the entry is indeed droplets through the respiratory system. So it can't be cured by breathing hot steam

Amid the coronavirus crisis, Italy’s streets are now filled with discarded printed cash as seen in photos circulating on social media. The photos were taken in Venezuela, not Italy. The discarded banknotes were Bolivar Fuerte, Venezuela’s old currency.

The electromagnetic waves of 5G penetrate the cells and weaken the immune system. The Italian STOP 5G committees connect electromagnetic waves with the coronavirus. They use a Thomas Cowan video on Youtube video as evidence, but there is no evidence to prove the theory.

Breathing steam from boiling citrus peels prevents and cures coronavirus. There is no way to increase your body temperature to kill the coronavirus, according to the WHO. Nigerian medical experts agreed that there was no evidence for the video's claims.
Filmmaker Sudhir Mishra getting beaten up by police during the lockdown for stepping out of home. The man getting beaten up by police is not filmmaker Sudhir Mishra.
Air India is operating evacuation flights to bring back stranded Indians from London. The Indian High Commission in London has denied the claim. There is no such immediate plan of evacuation.

Here’s the new certificate that the Ministry of the Interior is now requesting from citizens in order to leave their house. The Italian police has said that it's not the original version of the certificate, but a manipulated version of it.

President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya ordered credit reference bureaus to delist Kenyans who had defaulted on loans to protect Kenyans from the economic effects of COVID-19. President Kenyatta ordered the suspension of new listings for Kenyan citizens and businesses as one of the measures in response to COVID-19.
A new alcohol-free sanitizer has been developed by the Dedan Kimathi University in Kenya. The hand sanitizer developed by the Dedan Kimathi University actually contains alcohol.
Dr. Li Wenliang discovered coffee can cure coronavirus. Dr. Wenliang didn´t treat patients with COVID-19 and there is no evidence of benefits of coffee or the contrary.

In Colombia, former Uribista congressman Alfredo Rangel wrote on Twitter some data attributed to the Johns Hopkins University about the new coronavirus, causing the current COVID-19 pandemic. In particular, he said that his lethality “in Colombia is the third lowest in the world, after Chile and Germany” and added that “it is less 10 times than in Italy, 8 times than Spain, 6 than in Iran and 5 than in France “ The first part of the sentence is false because it does not correspond to the data of the mentioned American institution. The second is questionable because, in most cases, the comparison was close to the data available at the time, but the academic authorities in the field consider that this type of analysis is premature.
Inhalation of hot steam can kill the novel coronavirus. Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.
A claim that COVID-19 would have a deadline of “maximal infection” until April 3 in Brazil. According to experts, Brazil is still at the beginning of the growth curve of COVID-19.

Form in Portuguese being shared on WhatsApp for people to give personal data in order to receive government economic aid. Brazilian government had yet to release such economic aid and the form was a phishing scam.

A famous Brazilian doctor was defending the approach of “vertical social distancing.” Videos of member of Brazilian Congress Osmar Terra was erroneously attributed to cardiologist Adib Jatene, who died in 2014.

Photo shows food being distributed to Rwandans during coronavirus lockdown. The photos of piles of bedding and food are not from Rwanda, and have nothing to do with any coronavirus lockdown. They are of goods distributed by a sheikh in the Gambia during Ramadan, in May 2019.
Food was discarded after Sao Paulo’s governor decree Recording was from February; the state decree, about social distancing and closing non essential services, did not affect the warehouse.

Photo shows Italians prostrating themselves and praying to Allah, during the coronavirus crisis. The photo is from a Christian prayer vigil in Lima, Peru, on the nights of December 6 and 7, 2019. It has nothing to do with the coronavirus, and doesn't show Italians converted to Islam.

A video has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter and YouTube alongside a claim it shows people rioting and looting shops in England during the coronavirus lockdown. The claim is false. The video has circulated online since August 2011 about riots in the British capital of London.

Senegalese people flying back from Italy were killed on the spot at the Senegal airport. The video was about the full-scale test on airport security through simulated terrorist attacks at Blaise Diagne International Airport in Senegal on November 28, 2019.
Big Pharma is behind COVID-19 deaths. There is absolutely no evidence the "Big Pharma" companies are behind the virus.
CBS aired wrong video footage of a coronavirus hospital. CBS retracted the error, saying it occurred due to editing. The footage confused an Italian hospital with a New York hospital.
COVID-19 is a hoax or scapegoat for economic disaster. Claim came from conspiracy-related source and data and many reports worldwide confirm deaths from coronavirus.
World Economic Forum is a “fascist cabal” manipulating coronavirus. This is a conspiracy theory.
Amid the coronavirus pandemic, Health Minister of India is playing Ludo. The picture is almost one year old.
Politician Rahul Gandhi met a coronavirus patient in Waynad. The picture is from 2017.
An audio clip of Dr. Naresh Trehan cautioning people about the danger of COVID-19 in India. The audio is not of Dr. Trehan, nor has he said what is claimed in this audio recording.
Whether microwaving face masks sanitizes them. Research shows that hydrogen peroxide will kill the virus on masks, but no proof has been found that microwaving kills the novel coronavirus.

A post has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and on messaging app Line that claims Italy suffered a spike in novel coronavirus infections as a direct result of Italian citizens wearing shoes in their homes. The claim is misleading. Health experts told AFP that wearing shoes indoors cannot directly cause COVID-19 infections. Doctors recommend adopting through personal hygiene routines to lower the risk of COVID-19 infection.

World Health Organization (WHO) has advised people against eating bakery items amid COVID-19 outbreak. WHO Sri Lanka' has debunked the claim and clarified that WHO hasn't advised people against eating bakery items. The Press Information Bureau (PIB) has also debunked the claim and clarified the same.

Taking a flu shot causes false positive results on COVID-19 tests. The 2012 study cited in this claim only tested for coronaviruses that cause the common cold, but not COVID-19, which was not discovered until 2019. Furthermore, only one of 69 individuals who had received the flu shot tested positive for coronavirus—a frequency that precludes drawing a causal association between the flu shot and coronavirus detection.

A video of a ghost-like drone scaring people off the street has been viewed thousands of times on Facebook, Twitter, YouTube and Weibo alongside a claim that the footage shows a drone being used to enforce social distancing during the novel coronavirus pandemic in the Australian city of Brisbane. The claim is false; the video was published online in 2016 in a post about a prank in São Paulo, Brazil.

A photo shows Kabataan Representative Sarah Elago at the mountain of Barangay Puray, Rodriguez, Rizal attending the 51st anniversary of the New People’s Army (NPA). The photo of Elago on the mountaintop was not taken on March 29. It was part of a tweet that Elago herself posted on March 1, weeks before the March 29 NPA anniversary.

Some supermarkets took advantage of the epidemic to rise the prizes of consumer goods such as pasta in France. Leclerc, one of the biggest brand, ensured it was an "internal error", and according to consumer organization "UFC Que choisir", there was no global prize increase for consumer goods since the beginning of the epidemic

Video of dead bodies being thrown into a mass grave in Italy. The video is not of a real-life incident and it is also not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak in Italy. It is a clip from a movie - 'The Flu'.

This image of Pope Francis falling during a mass and thereafter testing postive for COVID-19. The photo is from 2016, when the Pope fell while celebrating mass in Poland. Pope Francis has not tested positive for coronavirus, and held a service at an empty St Peter’s Square in the Vatican on 28 March, three days after the post was published.

Drinking unsweetened black tea before the sun rises cures coronavirus. This was prophetised by a newborn baby, who died shortly after uttering the cure. There is no evidence that any kind of tea cures coronavirus. A virologist from the University of Nairobi confirmed that "tea cannot protect one from infection with COVID-19".

A 7 minutes video saying that COVID-19 is just a flu, and using misleading numbers to “prove” it. Dr Fauci indeed wrote on March 26 that coronavirus could have a mortality rate "flu-similar" of 0,1% but said in the same sentence that it could also be similar to the much worst flu pandemics of 1957 or 1968. Also, more important than the mortality rate is the contagion rate, to judge the severity of an epidemic.

A news article says that Russian president Vladimir Putin is supporting US president Donald Trump in stopping funding the World Health Organization. Putin has said that the WHO is evil and should be terminated. There is no evidence of Putin having made this statement and it has not been reported by any credible news organisation. Trump has announced that the US will stop funding the WHO, a decision which has been widely criticised, including by officials in Putin's government. Russia has not followed suit.

This picture shows trucks carrying dead bodies of COVID-19 victims and the accompanying post implies it is in Italy. This picture was taken in Paris and the trucks are not carrying dead bodies. However, Italy has had to use military trucks to move bodies during the crisis.

The Peruvian Ministry of Health and the WHO advised to use ginger to combat the new coronavirus. There is no evidence regarding the properties of ginger on the new coronavirus, and both health authorities denied having published said document.

The UK has assigned COVID-19 to the same group of infectious diseases as the seasonal flu. The exclusion of COVID-19 from the group of a high consequence infectious disease does not mean that it is assigned to the same group as the seasonal flu.

Sauna gives protection against COVID-19. A visit to the sauna is a great way to relax, but it cannot prevent an infection with SARS-CoV-2. The new coronavirus can survive for a short time in high temperatures and humidity. Even if you are already infected, a sauna visit cannot cure you, because your basal body temperature does not rise in a warm environment.

Ukraine lost a visa-free regime due to the coronavirus pandemic. The visa-free entry to the Schengen area holds. However, one cannot use it because of the prohibition of non-essential travels during the coronavirus pandemics.
Claim that scientists from John Hopkins University say that one can protect oneself against the new coronavirus with warm water and Listerine. University experts did not give such pieces of advice.

The number of deaths from the novel coronavirus is tiny in comparison to the other causes of deaths. The figures in the publication do not correspond to the real ones. The number of deaths from COVID-19 and e.g. cancer is not comparable due to the different nature of diseases.

A message asked people not to eat bakery food as it is not washable even if infected from the coronavirus, using a logo of the WHO. WHO never said it and the US FDA denied the claim as there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with the transmission of COVID-19.
Nostradamus predicted Coronavirus pandemic 500 years ago. Nostradamus did not predict about COVID-19 500 years ago.

As per Home Ministry of India, sharing information related to the coronavirus is now a punishable offense. We found that there is no official named Ravi Nayak in MHA, India, as claimed in the viral message. Also, there was no official notice on the website on MHA. It is evident from our fact check that the message viral on social media claiming to be from the Home Ministry of India is false.
Alleged resignation of the ministry of health in Costa Rica. "It is absolutely false," confirmed Minister of Communication Nancy Marín to La Nación.

In a video, the Ooni of Ife, a Nigerian traditional healer, says that plant products and sulphur can be used to treat COVID-19, and a vaccine for the disease can be extracted from the substances too. There is no cure for COVID-19, and no vaccine available for the disease yet, according to the WHO and medical experts. According to the US Centers for Disease Control, vaccines stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against certain diseases, and are developed from the actual disease-causing germs. Vaccines can't be "extracted" from "natural herbs".
The Spanish government stopped counting the dead from COVID-19 between March 6 and 9. On those days, the minister of health published data on social media and at a press conference.
The Spanish president’s wife and daughter went to Cuenca to quarantine. The presidency and town hall deny it.
Spanish authorities are not arresting people who attend mass. The video was filmed in October in the Valley of the Fallen.
Nike is giving away free shoes because of the new coronavirus. Nike denies this claim and there is no official information about it.
Huawei has stopped sending masks because of an article by Spanish writer Josep Borrell. Huawei says it is not true.
President Donald Trump announced commercialization of a vaccine. The text refers to a press conference where Trump did not say that. There is no vaccine yet.
A video from Italian TV predicted the coronavirus in 2015. The video does not refer to the actual virus.

A viral text based image post claiming that 5,000 from Italy were infected by mobile phone covers, quoting the findings were from a research without specifying any details or name of the research. The post advises to abandon phone covers. There has been no research proving 5,000 people from Italy are infected due to phone covers.

An image of arms burned by allegedly using gel alcohol to disinfect. Alcohol based gels (ethanol and isopropyl alcohol) are highly flammable if we expose ourselves to heat sources after applying them, but alcohol evaporates quickly if applied correctly.

A post claiming that Yangon region in Myanmar will be locked down within 48 hours says that announcement will come out officially. Yangon region minister for immigration and social welfare Daw Moe Moe Suu Kyi confirms that the news is false, and there is no plan to lockdown within 48 hours.

Image of bakery items with the WHO logo and a message which given the impression that WHO had advised the public not to consume bakery products amid COVID-19 concerns. The WHO has not issued any statement against consumption of bakery products and the FDA confirms there is no evidence of food or food packaging being associated with transmission of COVID-19.

Pope Francis asked believers to put a white handkerchief on their doorstep for the plague to go away. There is no reference to the pope's alleged request in any of the Vatican's official news services.

A video post related to coronavirus is circulating in social media saying China is distributing the Quran. We found this video is related to Chinese Christians. The Bible is seen for the first time and the video was originally shared in 2015.
A 20-second clip shows a burqa-clad woman having difficulty breathing. The video is not from Islampur in India, but is from Pakistan. The woman does not have the coronavirus.

The government was supposedly not buying evidence from a company related to the sister of María Dolores Cospedal, former secretary of the Popular Party, for ideological reasons. The government is buying tests for the coronavirus test from the company Genomica, of which the CEO is the sister of the former leader of the Popular Party.

Several photos of coffins, allegedly, with victims of the coronavirus for which the police are being investigated Four photos with a large number of coffins are disseminated with messages such as "the photo by which dozens of police and health officials are being investigated" or "images of the Spain that Pedro Sánchez is leaving us." It is a hoax. The photos correspond to a shipwreck in front of the island of Lampedusa (Italy) in October 2013.

The king of Spain can supposedly dissolve the congress and appoint an emergency government during the state of alarm. During the state of alarm, the Congress of Deputies cannot be dissolved. In addition, the acts of the king will always have to be approved and signed by the President of the Government or the Congress of Deputies and the dissolution of the Cortes can only occur in three specific cases, which do not include the current situation.

A video of an alleged seer who predicted the coronavirus in December 2019 There is no evidence that the video published by the seer, Nube de María, a few days ago was recorded and broadcast in December, as they claim.
Inhalation of hot steam can kill Novel Coronavirus. Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill COVID-19.

Tire repairer who died in a work accident was included in the death figures for COVID-19. In a note to Aos Fatos, Pernambuco's Department of Health reported that the death certificate of a 57-year-old man who circulates in social media publications is true, but the cause of death was rectified after further laboratory tests concluded that he died on account of another respiratory virus. The state agency also reported that the man's death was never included in state statistics as a result of COVID-19.

Increase in cases of pneumonia in Mexico. In Mexico, it is false that the cases of pneumonia and bronchopneumonia have registered an increase so far in 2020, according to the last report from the authority in mid-March. A rumor that some supposed 70 deaths linked to the new coronavirus has spread in networks, according to data that some businessmen from funeral homes in the Toluca Valley, State of Mexico, reportedly provided. This has been ruled out by some authorities and even by the same source to which the report was attributed.

President Donald Trump claims he “didn’t say that” some of the medical equipment that governors are requesting, they don’t actually need. During the interview with Hannity, Trump said, “I have a feeling that a lot of the numbers (for ventilators) that are being said in some areas are just bigger than they're going to be. I don't believe you need 40,000 or 30,000 ventilators.”

Pangolin proven to be “responsible” for coronavirus. No investigation to date has established with certainty that the pangolin, a mammal under protection that inhabits Asia and Africa, is part of the chain of species through which the coronavirus mutated and infected humans. The publications in which the “responsibility” of this species is reiterated are the result of the erroneous interpretation of investigations.

A post shared repeatedly on WhatsApp and Facebook claims a Chinese doctor has discovered that drinking tea is effective in curing and relieving symptoms of the novel coronavirus, COVID-19. The claim is false. Health experts say there is insufficient scientific evidence to show that drinking tea is effective in preventing or curing COVID-19 infections. As of March 2020, the WHO has said there is no cure for COVID-19.
Videos of a patient gasping for breath is shown as a patient from India. The video is not from India but Ecuador where the person was suffering from acute respiratory distress syndrome.
pH level of coronavirus varies from 5.5 to 8.5 and to beat the virus, we should consume more alkaline food. Dr. Shaheed Jameel, a leading virologist, said that viruses do not have pH values.
There is now a COVID-19 cure from the USA. It was a test kit from South Korea that was shared as an American-made vaccine for COVID-19.
Video of police roughing up civilians claimed to be police in Spain enforcing a lockdown. The video is originally from Baku, Azerbaijan, from a protest in October 2019.

The Indian Army has been called to control seven areas in Mumbai that are not following the 21 day lockdown and are out of the Mumbai police’s control. The Mumbai police have not called in the army and the seven areas are following the lockdown prescribed by the government.

The Indian Home Ministry considers posting anything about coronavirus a punishable offence. The message was attributed to a non-existent Home Ministry official and the ministry has not passed any circular stating that any message about coronavirus should not be shared.

Brazilian Ministry of Health hinted that relatives of COVID-19 victims should doubt the death certificates. The recommendation, which circulates on social media as if it were official, was denied by the Brazilian Ministry of Health's advisory and does not appear in the guidelines of the Brazilian government on the management of bodies in the context of the new coronavirus.

A photo has been shared hundreds of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it shows a hospital car park in Singapore which will be converted into wards during the novel coronavirus pandemic. The claim is misleading; the hospital clarified its car park would temporarily be used to test patients suspected to have been infected with the novel coronavirus, COVID-19, but it would not be converted into “wards”.

Video of Muslims applying their saliva to plates and spoons to spread the coronavirus disease. The first coronavirus case in the world was registered in December 2019. But the video is found to exist on social media at least since July 2018.

Video of police strictly implementing lockdown in Spain. The video is not related to a COVID-19 lockdown in any country. The video shows Azerbaijan Police (not Spain) dispersing a protest in October 2019.

Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak. It is an old photo. The photo was taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).

It is predicted that using Turmeric can cure coronavirus in India in a newborn baby suffering from birth defects. The baby was suffering from Anencephaly and was stillborn with no connection to COVID-19.

The French doctor Jean-Roger Hospital sent an email which claims you can protect yourself against COVID-19 by drinking water every 15 minutes. M. Hospital says he has been hacked. It is also false to claim that you can be protected by drinking water.

Website offers a rapid test for COVID-19 to check yourself in seconds. The website depends mainly on fever to diagnose COVID-19 even you said you have all other symptoms including dry cough, dyspnea and fatigue. The algorism will still say you are OK  and only have the common flu. The good part on the website is that it guides you when you have fever to go to the hospital for treatment.

“The Kaaba opened again” or “the Hajj was not stopped.” As such, the Kaaba did not close. On 2/27/20, the official website of the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia in connection with the spread of the coronavirus in the list of measures taken provides for a temporary suspension of the small pilgrimage. The Minister of Pilgrimage and Umrah of Saudi Arabia, Mohamed Saleh Benten, officially announced on his Twitter page that the small Hajj has been temporarily suspended. However, residents of the city can get into the mosque.

Multiple posts shared hundreds of times on Facebook and Twitter in March 2020 claim a new vaccine and a new drug have been developed to prevent and treat the novel coronavirus. The posts claim the developments were made by scientists in Japan and the Philippines respectively. The claims are misleading. The Japanese government announced in late March 2020 that Japanese scientists were testing a new drug, not a vaccine, to treat COVID-19; the Philippine Food and Drug Administration warned the other drug cited in the misleading posts was "unregistered" and not safe.
When you complete a registration for a 5,000 Baht support fund, it will show you a green sign, not a blue sign. The correct sign is blue.

A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple Facebook, Instagram and YouTube posts which claim it shows people in China toppling a 5G tower because of fears that it cause the novel coronavirus. The claim is false. The video shows pro-democracy protesters toppling a smart lamppost in Hong Kong in August 2019, several months before the novel coronavirus outbreak.

WHO advisory asks people not to consume bakery items as they get contaminated by coronavirus easily. The WHO has not issued any such advisory. There is no evidence that bakery items get easily contaminated by coronavirus.

Official news: in Naples people have used Tocilizumab, a drug that will cure COVID-19. The Italian Healthcare Ministry has authorized an experiment to understand whether this drug can be effective against COVID-19 pneumonia. However, this research has not proved anything yet.

Last week, the Valle del Lili Foundation in Cali summoned a press conference to speak about a “Treatment of infection with coronavirus (COVID-19).” It was “a treatment option through two medications such as: Hydroxychloroquine and Azithromycin, which can rapidly decrease the growth and expansion of the virus in the patient, decrease the possibility of serious illness or respiratory failure, as well as the possibility of contagion to others,” according to the press release. Treatment released by Cali clinic for COVID-19 does not yet have conclusive scientific evidence.

Video of a heartbreaking story of an Italian/Greek couple. Regardless of the risk of getting infected, a guy took off his protective suit and kissed his fiancee. They both died on March 25. The video is an edited clip of a 2010 Mexican soap drama, "Triunfo del amor."

Photo with a list of open community dining rooms in Bogotá. A list of community canteens in Bogotá is prowling on social networks, but it does not warn that these are not working in person and also omits the complete list.

A claim that India’s Ministry of Home Affairs has made it a “punishable offense” for citizens to publish posts on social media about the novel coronavirus has been shared repeatedly on Facebook, Twitter and WhatsApp. The claim is false. India’s official Press Information Bureau said it had made no such law. An online search for the purported government minister who issued the alleged ban yielded no results.
Inhalation of steam from hot water kills COVID-19 Inhalation of steam from hot water does not kill coronavirus. There is no research conducted to support the same.

A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. The claim is misleading. Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.

A photo of a Sri Lankan military hospital has been shared thousands of times in multiple Facebook posts alongside a claim that it has been reserved exclusively for the use of “VIPs” who test positive for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. The claim is misleading. Sri Lankan military and hospital authorities told AFP that the military hospital and the country's other medical facilities are being prepared for all COVID-19 patients.

An internet publication claimed that telecommunications company MTN is giving free internet data to people living in lockdown areas. MTN Ghana is not giving free internet data to its subscribers in the locked-down communities. The message is from MTN Nigeria and meant for subscribers in that country.
Did Kennedy Center give DNC $5 million after getting relief from coronavirus stimulus? At the time, no government relief funds had even been distributed yet, so it would have been impossible.

An ancient Egyptian food consisting of dry Corchorus Olitorius with lemon and garlic can prevent and cure COVID-19. The WHO mythbusted that garlic has any therapeutic effect in relation to COVID-19. The person who made the claim refuted it by saying it can't cure or prevent COVID-19.
COVID-19 not being blamed for deaths due to unrelated causes. Expert said there is incorrect information in this post.
As per Aajtak news channel, PM Narendra Modi announced a shutdown of internet services for a week. Screenshot is fake. PM Modi has not announced a shutdown of internet services.

Bollywood actor Shahrukh Khan donated 45 Crore (450 million) rupees to Pakistan. The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TVdebunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.

A video has been viewed tens of thousands of times in multiple Facebook, YouTube and Twitter posts alongside a claim it shows the Islamic call to prayer being heard in Spain during the COVID-19 epidemic for the first time in 500 years. The claim is false. The video was filmed in Azerbaijan in November 2019, before the COVID-19 pandemic. There has been no ban on the Islamic call to prayer in Spain in recent times.

G-7 countries have asked Modi to lead them in preventing coronavirus. UK Prime Minister, US President and Australian Prime Minister have not asked Modi to lead the G-7 countries in preventing coronavirus disease as stated in the video.

Photos of medicines from the US which will be only given to selected people by the Indian government in the name of COVID-19 treatment to eliminate them. The photos are neither related to India nor the US. The photos were taken at Kota Kinabalu International Airport (Sabha, Malaysia) when the health equipment donated by the Chinese Government reached the airport.

CEOs got advance notice of COVID, then resigned to dump stock. The post listed 14 companies. But only two had CEOs who stepped down from their posts, and left their companies, since the coronavirus first surfaced in China. We found no evidence that CEOs’ departures were related to the coronavirus or that they sold company stock after receiving advance information about it.

Video of dead bodies being thrown into a mass grave in Italy. The video is not of a real-life incident and it is also not related to the current COVID-19 outbreak in Italy. It is a clip from a movie - 'The Flu'.

French Astrologer Nostradamus had predicted in 1551 that there would be an outbreak of coronavirus in China in 2020. No such prediction was ever made by Nostradamus. The prediction is being circulated only recently after the COVID-19 outbreak.

Johns Hopkins University published a list of instructions that can help protect us from the new coronavirus. The text is a mix of correct and unsubstantiated instructions regarding SARS-CoV-2 which has no connection to Johns Hopkins University.

A Facebook user suggested that palm oil can stop the spread of COVID-19. The World Health Organisation did not list palm oil as one of its preventive measures to stop the spread of the COVID-19. There’s also no study that shows that it can stop or cure coronavirus. Currently, there is still no definitive cure or vaccine for COVID-19; there are, however, ongoing pre-clinical and clinical trials.

Don’t left alcohol gel in your car, it could burn and explode. Even if alcohol gel is inflammable,  it couldn't cause a fire by itself in a car. A flame from another source is need for it to catch on fire.

The chief minister of the state of Madhya Pradesh said that since the lockdown restrictions were not being adhered to effectively, all the houses will be locked from outside starting April 1, 2020. No such appeal has been circulated from the state's chief minister. The message is fake.

The photos of Ukrainian hospitals show that they are not ready, at the end of March, to accept patients with COVID-19. The photos used in the publications are old photos of hospitals from Russia and Russian-occupied Ukrainian territories.
Inhaling steam kills the coronavirus. Inhaling steam does not kill coronavirus.

Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan tested COVID-19 positive. Pakistan's Senator Faisal Javed Khan clearing the air, denied the claim, further asked the news network to correct the report. The Pakistani politician said, "News regarding PM Imran Khan tested positive for COVID-19 is not true. Please refrain from spreading fake news."

Pakistan’s Dr. Usama Riaz, who contracted coronavirus while treating patients, had left a video message before he died. The various social media posts claiming that the person in the video is Dr. Usama Riaz are misleading. The man in the recording is Mubhasir Ahmed, who has been living in the United Kingdom.
Boiled sumac cures COVID-19. The person makes the claim is a cleric, not a scientist. There is no evidence that shows sumac cures the disease.
The current coronavirus outbreak is due to the movement toward 5G. The 5G connection has no scientific evidence to the outbreak of coronavirus.

The coronavirus spreads in the air for eight hours. COVID-19 seems to spread mainly through respiratory droplets and close contact. The droplets are too large to be transported by air for long periods of time

The viral text message claims that the chemical substances (methylxanthines) required to cure COVID-19 can be found in tea. Dr. Li Wenliang had found this cure while researching about coronavirus before his death. A veteran microbiologist in India, Dr. Sharad Kale, dismissed such reports saying, though methylxanthines are found in tea, there is no scientific evidence it cures coronavirus. He called it a hoax. The WHO also states there is no evidence that current medicine can prevent or cure the disease.

A viral video post claiming that Myanmar people have resistance to coronavirus. The narration says that since Myanmar people eat rice, fish paste and vegetables, they don’t need to worry about coronavirus infections as their immune systems are stronger than those of people from the west. There is no evidence or recommendation from the WHO for possible COVID-19 prevention by taking a certain food. ABC News quoted two experts saying no single food is a supercharger for the immune system. Mohs confirmed three COVID-19 cases two days after the viral video made such a claim.
Huawei stopped donating masks to Europe. Huawei denied that it has stopped sending masks to support Europe, and has not issued an official statement.

The co-founder of the Union, Progress and Democracy (UPyD) party, Rosa Díe allegedly tweeted that she says “it is time for the Army to take over …” to handle the emergency. There are no archive that shows this tweet ever existed.

An alleged tweet from the president of the Vox political party in Spain, Santiago Abascal, in which someone has to answer for the infected including a misspelling. There is no evidence that Santiago Abascal has tweeted this message or that he has deleted it. The tweet is neither published nor archived and the catch that circulates is always the same.
Bolivian former Health minister Ariana Campero used an image in a twitter post to criticize the government. The image is from Ecuador.

A declaration by the director of the Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies of Spain about tests of COVID-19 for health personnel. Fernando Simón, director of the Center for Coordination of Health Alerts and Emergencies of Spain, said health personnel in contact with an infected colleague with COVID-19 during a public speech was denied by the Health Ministry, the protocols and the personnel.
A viral post claiming there is a French state scandal about chloroquine, with 20 different claims. Most of the claims are false or out of context.

Photo shows a man was cured of COVID-19 by hydroxychloroquine. The image is from a 2019 Brazilian RBS report, prior to the coronavirus pandemic and any case recorded worldwide. The man is Walter Hugo Balestra Pombo, a patient with pulmonary emphysema admitted to the ICU of the Moinhos de Vento hospital in Porto Alegre due to treatment for pulmonary emphysema.
The title of the article states: “The first pregnant woman with coronavirus in Macedonia gave birth.” The assertion in the headline is false. It is an event that happened in Serbia.
News graphic saying Indian prime minister has asked for the internet to be shut down in the country. The news graphic is photoshopped and fake. The prime minister did not make this statement.

A news publication reports the Royal Palace confirms Queen Elizabeth tests positive for coronavirus. While we cannot know if Queen Elizabeth does not have COVID-19, no evidence suggests she does. Besides, no notable publications corroborate this assertion. Although she came in contact with Boris Johnson, Prime Minister of England, who has a positive COVID-19 status, no reports definitively say she has undergone a test. Rather, credible intel suggests she is “following all the appropriate advice with regards to her welfare."

A website claiming that China has confirmed that patient zero had sex with a bat. World News Daily is a website generating fake news and it is scientifically seen that the virus has emerged from an animal source.
Bombay High Court is extending Maharashtra’s lockdown to April 31. The High Court had only extended its interim orders and not the lockdown.

Myanmar’s former military junta donated Ks 1000 Lakhs to COVID-19 fund. The list of donors in The Mirror daily circulated on March 26 shows no name of former military junta or current army chief or former president.

Audio from the Secretary of Risk Management for Cali on the exponential growth of coronavirus. The voice is not from politician Rodrigo Zamorano but from the doctor César Augusto Arias, interviewed on a radio program.

The following statement: “There are prisoners infected with the coronavirus; the state is hiding this fact.” This false information was denied by the Directorate for Execution of Sanctions and Minister of Health Venko Filipce, one day later.

A headline: “Latest News / Something Big is Happening in Europe.” This is blank text, no information, no facts, no source of information and nothing that can serve the reader. The purpose of this article is only to cause panic and to collect as many clicks as possible. The text is no longer available.

Multiple news reports circulating in Nigeria claim that Buckingham Palace has announced Britain’s Queen Elizabeth tested positive for COVID-19. Although the queen’s eldest son was diagnosed with the disease, the Palace said the monarch herself is “in good health”.

Neem leaves can cure COVID-19. The WHO has said that while some traditional medicines, western medicines and home remedies may provide comfort and alleviate symptoms of COVID-19, there is no evidence of a single medicine that treats COVID-19.

Putting eucalyptus (Vicks VapoRub) in the nose prevents COVID-19. Eucalyptus has some antiseptic and anti-inflammatory properties, but is not virucidal and there is no evidence that it fights SARScov-2.
Water vapor inactivates COVID-19. There is no evidence supporting hot water as a preventive measure.

India TV telecasted news that Bollywood Actor Shahrukh Khan donated 450 million (45 Crore) Rupees to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims. The video is a clipped version of India TV’s fact-check video. In the original fact-check video, India TV has debunked the same claim and concluded that Shahrukh has not made any donation to Pakistan Oil tanker blast victims.

Video of a person infected with coronavirus committing suicide in New York. The video was taken in 2015. It shows a pregnant woman jumping off a building after finding that her husband was having an affair with her mother.

Recent photo of PM Modi visiting a church and offering prayers to save the country from the coronavirus outbreak. It is an old photo, taken when Modi visited Sri Lanka in June 2019. He paid homage to those killed in the serial bombings at St. Anthony's Shrine (Colombo, Sri Lanka).

Indian Army has built a 1,000-bed hospital in Rajasthan in eight days for the treatment of COVID-19. The news that it is building a thousand-bed hospital for the treatment of COVID-19 in Barmer (Rajasthan) is false. The photos in the post are old.

A video of a man committing suicide by jumping from a hotel in Italy after his entire family died because of the coronavirus. The video has been on the internet since December 2019. The first death due to COVID-19 was reported in January 2020. So there is no relation between the video and COVID-19. Also, the hotel in the video is in Spain.
Video of police strictly implementing a lockdown in Spain. The video is not related to a COVID-19 lockdown in any country. It shows Azerbaijan Police (not Spain) dispersing a protest in October 2019.
“Queen Elizabeth tests positive for COVID-19.” No credible reports claim that Queen Elizabeth II tested positive for COVID-19. Buckingham Palace recently said she remains in good health.

Says COVID-19 remains in the air for eight hours and that everyone is now required to wear masks “everywhere.” There are different definitions of what is considered “airborne,” and while COVID-19 is spread through the air via droplets, it isn’t believed to be as transmissible as typical airborne illnesses, such as measles. There is no evidence that the virus stays in the air for eight hours and there is no requirement for “everyone” to wear masks everywhere.

Posts shared more than 20,000 times on Facebook feature a photo of a crying child and two others showing a woman and a man in hospital beds, claiming that the boy’s parents are infected with the novel coronavirus This is false. The pictures do not depict a family prior to the COVID-19 pandemic.

Says a “5G Law Passed while everyone was distracted” with the coronavirus pandemic and lists 20 symptoms associated with 5G exposure. While some experts are concerned about the potential health effects of 5G, there is no evidence to support the symptoms listed in the post.

Pictures and reports of “empty hospitals” prove COVID-19 spread is “fake crisis for real government planned agendas.” There are hospitals with significant numbers of empty beds — but not because of a conspiracy that exaggerates the coronavirus outbreak.

Audio clips from a doctor who works for Argentina’s most important lab testing for coronavirus. The lab denied the alleged doctor work there. Much of the advice given in the audio clip was denied by specialist.

A comparison of the evolution of the coronavirus in Argentina and Chile. Specialists indicated that the data in the post is not enough to compare objectively the evolution of the pandemic in each country.

COVID-19 affects mainly people with type A blood (group II). The articles refer to the Medrxiv website, which cannot serve as a reliable source of scientific knowledge. The figures in the study are very controversial and it is impossible to draw a final conclusion from them.
Official statement of the Serbian Government claiming that experts recommended to ban pet walks. Experts involved in Crisis Headquarter fighting against COVID-19 denied the government's claim.
Viral post along with a pictures claims civilian thrashing a policeman during lockdown. The viral photos are three years old and have nothing to do with the coronavirus lockdown.
CDC recommends that people shave their facial hair to prevent coronavirus. No such recommendations have been made by the CDC so far.
Inhaling the steam of sea salt and orange peelings can prevent coronavirus infection. There is no scientific proof of the claim; the WHO does not mention this remedy.

“These are the coffins of people that have died from COVID-19. Would you now stay at home, you idiots?” This image is from 2013 and shows the coffins of migrants who died crossing the Mediterranean Sea.

Screenshots of messages showing emergency cash transfers from the Government of Kenya in response to COVID-19. The government of Kenya had not introduced any emergency cash transfers and had not announced cash transfers as a response to COVID-19 in the country.

A front page article by the Southern Times cautioning against travel to Kenya because of the growing number of cases in Kenya. The Southern Times published a post denouncing the front page, and the image appears to be a doctored version of a previous edition of the paper.

Russia released lions in the streets forcing people to quarantine. The photo is originally from a lion that was used to record a movie in South Africa in 2016, while the fake headline was created in a meme generator.
The number of COVID-19 cases we hear about is fake. Many of the statements in the video are false or exaggerated.

A Facebook user attributed a post to ex-President Mahama, saying he will not donate his money to support COVID-19 fight. Former President John Dramani Mahama has not said he will not donate toward the fight against coronavirus. On the contrary, he has already made donations to the Greater Accra Regional Hospital (GARH) to help fight COVID-19.

Sao Paulo governor’s decree artificially raises the number of COVID-19 deaths. After the president questioned the number of deaths in São Paulo related to the pandemic of the new coronavirus, groups spread falsely that a change on death certificate procedures would cause it.

A video says that a Japanese doctor has proven that coronavirus is airborne. Therefore, it’s critical to wear face masks. The video was originally from the special program of Japanese national broadcasting service, NHK, on March 22. The program presented the experiment suggesting the transmission through aerosols, but it didn't say that coronavirus is airborne. Through the expert brought up the possibility of aerosols causing cluster infection in the program, he also emphasized that keeping proper ventilation can reduce the transmission.
Whether CDC had scheduled announcement that all should wear masks for everyday life. At the time, the CDC confirmed they had nothing scheduled.
If Florida banned alcohol sales due to coronavirus. Story came from a prank news generator.

French State approved a medical protocol with Plaquenil, lopinavir/ritonavir to cure COVID-19, which is more expensive than Pr. Raoult’s protocol with chloroquine. The authorities didn't approve this protocol, even if those medicines are currently tested, and the comparisons between the two protocols are misleading.
Amid COVID-19 pandemic, MP government ordered houses locked from April 1, 2020. MP government has not issued any such order.
As per the video, Bollywood actor Aamir Khan donated 250 crore to fight aganist COVID-19. The video is six years old.

Global temperature, CO2 in atmosphere and ozone hole has decreased in two months of quarantine. The ozone layer has improved steadily since 1987 when Montreal Protocol was signed, but in 2020 scientists discovered an increase in the North Pole hole. Neither Co2 nor temperature has decreased air pollution, but the image doesn't picture that.
WHO announces Algeria outside of danger regarding COVID-19. WHO department in Algeria denied this allegations. till 12 april 2020 Algeria is still following lockdown rules like other countries.
Queen Elizabeth II has been diagnosed with coronavirus. Queen Elizabeth II has not been diagnosed with coronavirus.

A video shows right wing blogger Billy Six who filmed himself in an empty hospital to prove that there is no crisis, there are no patients and nobody is sick. Billy Six was not in the part of the hospital where the COVID-19 patients are treated. His claims about the situations of hospitals are misleading, the clinic comfirmed that there are patients.

A news site, Adepanews, stated that the Ghana Health Service announced a 100% COVID-19 recovery rate. Not only did the Ghana Health Service fail to mention the afforementioned fact, as at the date of posting- March 28, the Service indicated a total of 141 confirmed active cases in the country.
MMS drug cures COVID-19 There is no specific treatment for COVID-19. MMS can be harmful and should not be consumed, according to WHO and other health agencies around the world.
BCG vaccine protects from COVID-19. For now, there is no evidence that BCG vaccine can protect from COVID-19.

Drinking two spoonfuls of palm oil daily protects against coronavirus, according to the World Health Organization. There are currently no drugs licensed for the treatment or prevention of COVID-19, says the WHO. The WHO have not said that palm oil can cure or prevent the disease. There is no evidence to support this advice.
Biomagnetic resonance can help to treat COVID-19. Biomagnetic resonance is pseudoscience and has no medical basis for use as a treatment for any medical condition including COVID-19.

The vaccine for coronavirus is ready. US President Donald Trump has announced that Roche Medical Company will launch it. Few unrelated images and videos have been put together to make this false claim. A vaccine has not been developed for the novel coronavirus.

A COVID-19 patient was caught by the police in the Gorakhpur district in the state of Uttar Pradesh, India. The video is of a mock drill conducted by the district police to tackle coronavirus, and the person caught in the video is just a subject for the drill and not a COVID-19 patient.

Northern Ireland Government has contingency plans for COVID-19 include turning Dundonald Ice Bowl into a morgue to store bodies temporarily. The Department of Justice confirms that there are no plans to use either Dundonald Ice Bowl or the SSE Arena. The Justice Minister has stated that buildings on the Kinnegar site outside Holywood will be used as the Northern Ireland Temporary Resting Place if required.

Pakistan’s PM Imran Khan tested COVID-19 positive. Pakistan's Senator Faisal Javed Khan clearing the air, denied the claim, further asked the news network to correct the report. The Pakistani politician said, "News regarding PM Imran Khan tested positive for COVID-19 is not true. Please refrain from spreading fake news."

Pakistan’s Dr. Usama Riaz, who contracted coronavirus while treating patients, had left a video message before he died. The various social media posts claiming that the person in the video is Dr. Usama Riaz are misleading. The man in the recording is Mubhasir Ahmed, who has been living in the United Kingdom.

Dr. Lidija Gajski claims that COVID-19 is usual cold, that Croatia had the strictest measures in the world, and calls for violations of the measures because they are unfounded This is a second part of an analysis regarding restrictive measures by Croatian national authorities during the COVID-19 pandemic given by the internal medicine specialist from Croatia, dr. Lidija Gajski. Dr. Gajski calls the disease COVID-19 a flu and makes a number of incorrect claims bordering with conspiracy theory. Her claim that COVID-19 is usual flu is false as two different viruses from the corona family cause two different diseases - flu and COVID-19. Some of her other claims have no basis in science, while others have been greatly overrun by the reality of a pandemic.

Italy has surrendered to the coronavirus pandemic as all the measures to control COVID-19 have been exhausted. Prime Minister of Italy Giuseppe Conte in his recent statement said: "We are giving up the most expensive habits, we do it because we love Italy, but we do not give up courage and hope in the future. United, we will do it." He did not talk about surrendering.

Amitabh Bachchan gave 500 million rupees to the Mumbai government to fight the coronavirus. A part of an old video of Amitabh Bachchan and Narendra Modi is viral with false claims. Amitabh has not given a check of Rs. 500 crores to Bombay Municipal Corporation nor to Government of Maharashtra. He has not even met Indian  Prime Minister Narendra Modi recently.

Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with a capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19. The viral images claiming the Indian Army has constructed an advanced hospital with the capacity of 1,000 beds in Barmer, Rajasthan, to cope with COVID-19 are old and unrelated.

A Matt Damon movie trailer that predicts the coronavirus pandemic. A video of the trailer for the movie "Contagion" starring Matt Damon in 2011 is being used to say that it is a brand-new movie produced in 2019 that predicted the coronavirus pandemic.

Hot baths can help prevent the coronavirus. Using WHO recommendations, we advise that the best way to prevent the coronavirus is hand washing and we warn of the risk of burns from extremely hot baths.

Indian State of Kerala Opposition leader writes to Chief Minister Pinarayi Vijayan to adopt methods to save only those with stronger immunity from COVID-19 infection. FactCrescendo obtained the letter. The opposition leader has suggested only mitigation measures to be adopted by the state to stop the spread of coronavirus. The Facebook user has misinterpreted the term "mitigation methods" and built a false narrative around it. The opposition leader's office has condemned the post saying no politician occupying the post of the leader of the opposition would suggest such drastic measures.

Indian Prime Minister Modi announced an internet ban due to the spread of misinformation regarding COVID-19. Fact Crescendo found the viral claim to be false as the image is digitally edited from an ABP News Hindi bulletin aired on 3/24/20 when PM Narendra Modi had announced a nationwide 21 day lockdown due to the outbreak of COVID-19.

Video post showing that conflict between villagers and police in India as a COVID-19 suspected corpse was carried to the cemetery. This particular village had such conflicts in the past three years for carrying a corpse through the village lane. The local police chief has confirmed that the death has nothing to do with COVID-19.
Claim that Saint Corona has always been a patron saint against epidemics. Saint coronavirus was never specifically worshiped as the patron saint against epidemics before March 2020.
A herd of deer reclaimed the Ooty-Coimbatore road. The viral image is from Japan's Nara, taken in 2014. It has no connection with India or the lockdown.

In the 30-second viral video, a man lifts his shirt and challenges aa police officer who is pointing a gun at him. Another police officer kicks the man from behind, pins him down on the road and makes an arrest. The text overlaid on the video reads “Italy says lockdown, they mean it.” Upon investigation, we found out that the video is from Brazil and has nothing to do with lockdown or coronavirus. The man was drunk and was scaring people with a knife in hand. The police of Sao Paulo has to use force to make the arrest.

President Donald Trump attending the recital of Quran verses to fight coronavirus. The video is from 2017, when Trump and his wife Melania attended the inaugural prayer service after taking the oath as the 45th president of the United States. Imam Mohammad Majid, executive director of the All Dulles Area Muslim Society, recited verses from the Quran.

A photo with a message of a doctor crying saying that the coronavirus is stronger than science. A photo of Pep Guardiola, Manchester City football team trainer, is being related to a message saying he is the head of the Madrid Hospital Department, Felipe Monterroso, crying inconsolably and saying that the coronavirus "is stronger than science, but not stronger than God."

An image claiming that Vladimir Putin said that the United States created coronavirus as a biological weapon. One image says Russia's President Vladimir Putin said President Donald Trump made the coronavirus a biological weapon against China and that humanity is now paying for its mistake. There is no evidence that the Russian president has said this.

An online survey to self-assess coronavirus symptoms. A questionnaire created in Google Forms circulates for people to do a self-assessment on the symptoms of the disease. It was created by a foundation, and it is real, but it is not from any official institution.
An emergency department closed in a Spanish hospital. Videos are real. But the emergency department wasn't closed in Leganés. It was full and a lot of patients had to wait in the corridor.
A video claiming bodies packed in body bags are being dumped in mass graves in Italy and Spain. The video is from a 2007 sci-fi mini series called "Pandemic."

Images showing vaccines for coronavirus have already been discovered, were patented and will be readily available. Images of test kits and patents of other coronavirus strains are being falsely shared as COVID-19.
Indian Home Minister Amit Shah claimed to be infected with COVID-19. The news graphic was created from a news generator and the news that the Home Minister has COVID-19 is not true.

The Netflix Korean drama “My Secret Terrius” predicted the coronavirus outbreak in 2018. The show discusses coronavirus, a family of viruses causing flu like symptoms. The symptoms mentioned are very different from COVID-19 and the fatality rate is much higher.
False measures of coronavirus in Bogota. The image shows how this measure will be applied in the municipality of Apartadó, Antioquia.
An image of a elderly man’s death in Italy. The image was taken in Wuhan, China.
Alleged images of markets that have been sacked by angry mobs because of the lockdown, in São Paulo. Images were from 2013.

H1N1 was far more damaging to Brazil than COVID-19: the number of cases and deaths was far higher. Although the figures are somewhat accurate, they correspond to different timeframes. Data for COVID-19 amounts for the first 24 days of epidemic. The figures for H1N1 are from July 2009 to December 2010. On the first 24 days of H1N1 epidemic in Brazil, there were only 16 confirmed cases, and no one had died.

Israel applied “vertical lockdown” (younger, not at risk people are allowed to carry on their daily routines), and has the lowest death rate for COVID-19 in the world. Although Israel does have one of lowest death rates in the world, they did not restrict their lockdown policies to elderly people.

Bollywood superstar Aamir Khan donated Rs. 250 crore to tackle the novel coronavirus outbreak. The image on social media claiming that Bollywood star Aamir Khan has donated Rs 250 crore to fight the novel coronavirus is misleading as the actor has not donated anything yet. British boxer Amir Khan has offered his retail outlet to the NHS to help COVID-19 patients.

Indian businessman, WIPRO chairman and philanthropist Azim Prem donated 50,000 Crore to fight the COVID-19 outbreak in India. Several media outlets used an old statement by Azim Premji to back their claim that Premji has donated INR 50,000 crore to fight COVID-19 outbreak in India. The same media reports were amplified by several verified Twitter handles including journalists, media personalities and politicians.
Coronavirus has been found in crab legs. The meme is from a bogus news-generating app. Crab legs are safe, health experts confirm.

Telephone networks are about to collapse in Mexico. Several messages have circulated about the possibility of collapse in cell phone companies due to the high traffic that has occurred in recent weeks amid the new coronavirus pandemic.
COVID-19 is destroyed with the “hair dryer” technique. False cure using a hair dryer to destroy virus.
Some cities in Turkey are going to be disinfected by helicopters. Both national and local authorities denied the measure.
Council of Higher Education in Turkey announced the spring term has already been over. Spring semester is not over; higher education is going to continue remotely.
Netflix gives spoiler on city screens to discourage people from going out. Billboards were not prepared by Netflix but by a creative art group.

Two articles claiming that iconic coffee chain Tim Hortons will close all Canada franchises on 3/30/20 because of the novel coronavirus were shared more than 150,000 times on Facebook. This claim is false. Though locations are closed to dining-in, drive-throughs remain open, a spokeswoman for the chain told AFP.

News ticker added to an image from Sri Lankan Ada Derana TV channel gives the impression that Dr Seetha Arambepola stated there is a secret medicine for COVID-19 during a TV interview We contacted Dr. Seetha Arambepola and cross checked with the video interviews and image comparison and confirmed a statement she had made on a different TV interview had been misinterpreted.

A video claims to be of Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau’s wife Sophie Grégoire Trudeau who is infected with coronavirus. The woman in the video is not Sophie Trudeau, but a British woman who has been infected with COVID-19.

This is a picture of the old city in Hyderabad (India) today despite the lockdown. The video is an old one. It was not taken during the current lockdown. Also, today’s Friday prayer at Mecca Masjid was conducted with only a few members.

A licensed guide from Rome and the Vatican named Katya tells what is really going on with the coronavirus epidemic in Italy. Several statements do not correspond to scientific facts and official statements.
Italian PM said that the country has surrendered to the COVID-19 pandemic The quote attributed to the Italian PM is fabricated.

A Facebook post suggests that a scientist in the United States has found a cure for coronavirus. There is currently no cure for COVID-19. A breakthrough suggesting otherwise would warrant notice of international TV coverage, not a mere social media posting or blog site.

Inhaling the steam from boiled water with dissolved salt is an effective cure for COVID-19, the disease caused by the novel coronavirus. There is still no cure approved to treat the novel coronavirus, but there are treatments approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration that may help ease the symptoms. Inhaling salt water steam is not among them.

“A few hours ago, China officially announced the success of the Cuban serum that Dr. Hala, Cuba’s Minister of Health, presented to the Chinese Ministry of Health to treat the coronavirus , which turned out to be 100% effective in more than seven cases that have been cured” China has not announced anything of the sort.
Italian priest died, refusing to use respirator as he sacrificed it to a younger person. He didn't sacrifice the respirator. He didn't use it due to medical conditions.

French professor Didier Raoult, director of IHU Marseille, told Africans not to take “Bill Gates’ vaccine” against coronavirus because it is “poisonous.” The IHU Marseille has denied that its director made such comments, and there is currently no vaccine or approved treatment. If scientific research is underway, no vaccine should be released until at least next year.
Venezuelan YouTuber Ruby Demestoy talked about Event 201, Bill Gates and VIH and SARS conspiracies. Well-known conspiracies and many others lack precise scientific information.
The WHO admitted the coronavirus is transmitted because it is in the air for 8 hours. Using a real CNBC link claimed the opposite of what the WHO discovered and found.

Boil weed and ginger for COVID-19 victims, and the virus will vanish. There is no evidence supporting the claim that marijuana and ginger can cure COVID-19. To date, there is no specific treatment available for COVID-19, although clinical trials evaluating certain existing drugs are underway.

A sensationalist headline claiming that there is a new virus in China, the hantavirus. Passengers have been isolated and tested because of the suspicion that the coronavirus may be the cause of the deteriorating health of the passenger, not because of the danger of transmitting the hantavirus. The hantavirus first appeared in 1950.

A Chinese study is the definitive proof that chloroquine works. A widely shared video claims that Chinese studies prove chloroquine cures almost all of COVID-19 patients. Even though there have been some encouraging initial results, the researchers are in fact very cautious.
Video of mass grave claiming to be Italy. This is from the movie "Pandemic."

You have to take off your clothes and shoes outside and wash them with disinfectants. The virus sticks to the floor for nine hours and also spreads via the wind. The claims lack context or are unproven. It is sufficient to wash your clothes normally. There are no studies regarding the lifespan of the virus on the floor.
By clicking on an italian YouTube song, you donate money to a hospital in Bergamo. Direct clicks are not giving out money, but the singer on the video said he would donate proceeds.

Video of a waitress saying, “I lost my job. But I’ll sleep better knowing” that the coronavirus relief bill included funding for the Kennedy Center, refugee resettlement, PBS, and congressional salaries: “Thanks, Democrats.” The post accurately cites several provisions that are in the coronavirus relief bill passed in late March. But it’s misleading to suggest the financial needs of a laid-off waitress aren't addressed in the bill.

Seven photos have been shared repeatedly in multiple posts on Facebook and Twitter, alongside a claim that they show vegetables donated to disadvantaged people during a curfew prompted by the novel coronavirus pandemic in Sri Lanka. The photos have been shared in a misleading context; they actually show vegetables being donated at an event in southern Sri Lanka in August 2019, more than eight months before the curfew was implemented.
Photo of deer on Ooty-Coimbatore road during the current lockdown (COVID-19). It is an old photo, on the internet at least since 2014. It was taken in Japan, not in India.

“Mainstream media” used a photo from a 2017 movie as an image for Italy’s coronavirus morgue. The original photo is from a 2013 news report showing an airport hangar filled with coffins of African migrants who died in a shipwreck near an Italian island. It has not appeared in any recent media reports.
RAI TV news report from 2015 proves COVID-19 was made in a Chinese laboratory. The news report in question was not related to COVID-19.
COVID-19 no longer considered a dangerous disease in the UK. The false claim misrepresents UK's system for disease classification.
5G is the cause of the coronavirus pandemic. Neither 5G nor other means of electromagnetic transmission are causing virus epidemics.

“They’re furloughing nurses in hospitals in western New York state.” Hospitals in Buffalo and Rochester said they were preparing for a surge of patients, not furloughing nurses. Some health care workers have been furloughed elsewhere as elective surgeries have been canceled to stop the spread of the coronavirus.

A claim that 500 body bags were delivered to an ice skating rink outside the Australian city of Adelaide has been shared widely on Facebook during the novel coronavirus pandemic. The claim is false. South Australian health authorities said the claim is a “myth” and a spokesperson for the local ice rink said “the rumour is completely false."

Biden claims that Trump did not try to get medical experts into China. Biden could make a case that Trump’s efforts to gain access for medical experts to China lacked vigor or were ineffectual; he cannot say there was no effort. As for being foresighted enough to make this case early on, Biden did not explicitly call for it until near the end of February, so that appears exaggerated.

Eight regions in Perú have no plan to manage the coronavirus crisis. Four of the mentioned regions already had emergency plans for the coronavirus crisis and published them before the Ombudsman claim.

The Argentine vice president flew to her home state and violated the quarantine. She was not on the flight indicated by the viral post. She is also exempt from the quarantine, as are all high ranking government officials.

Series of WhatsApp chains offering sums of money “from the national government and the WHO” and food packages from Walmart. All of them shared Google forms to sign up. The WHO isn't offering financial aid directly to people. This is the same disinformation circulated in other countries. Walmart isn't giving away food packages.
Car insurance won’t cover damage to your vehicle during the quarantine. This was denied by the state agency in charge of insurers.

A recipe involving a full lemon and ground cloves has cured a woman’s COVID-19 symptoms. She isn’t sure she and her maid actually had COVID-19, but she still encourages people who think they have it to take this recipe. There is no evidence that full lemon and ground cloves can cure COVID-19.

59 people from Kenya die after drinking Dettol when Prophet Rufus Phala of AK Spiritual Christian Church told them to do so to prevent COVID-19 infection. The incident is correct but not related to COVID-19 as it happened in 2016. The priest defended himself that the Dettol will transfer to water or juice with God's permission while they are drinking it.

Boiled eggs can treat coronavirus. The video used to complete the narration is edited. There has been no vaccine or drug to prevent or treat COVID-19, including eggs. Eggs are recommended for consumption to boost the immune system.

Italian President Mattarella: “Italy will declare a life-long quarantine” President Mattarella never made the statement. Errors made in the distributed passage indicate that the text is likely to be the product of poor-quality automatic translation. This is the first sign that the authenticity of the message is in doubt, and needs to be verified in detail.

Houses should be heated above 23 degrees Celsius because the new coronavirus can only “spread at low temperatures”. There is no scientific evidence to support this theory. There is no connection between the death of the virus and the temperature of the houses.
